div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette The English Daily Newspaper.
div.p: Established 1880.
Editor and Manager - R. Snelling.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
Monday, November 5, 1906
GOLD FOR EGYPT
Commenting on the monetary situation, the "Statist" says that there continues to be a very remarkable difference of opinion amongst those in the best position to judge

as to whether the Egyptian demand for gold is or is not ended. There appears no doubt that money is already flowing back from the provinces to Cairo, and a great many of the best authorities are of opinion that now the return flow will be so large as completelyto stop the imports of gold. On the other hand, a high authority is of opinion that the demand is not ended; that although money may now be expected to return to Cairo in considerable amounts, further imports of gold will continue to be made for an indefinite time. But the authority does not venture upon any estimate as to the amount likely to be taken. It would seem from all this that the demand, which was caused by the earliness of the cotton crop, and the desire of the growers to take immediate advantage of the very high prices prevailing, is really now practically satisfied-at all events will be satisfied by the middle of next week. On the other hand, it is alleged that hoarding is going on on a very considerable scale. Hoarding is characteristic of all countries in a backward state of development.It is universal in the East, and Egypt is still an Eastern country. Therefor, it is quite possible that more gold may be taken for Egypt, although the majority of those in a position to judge think that we may regard the demand as practically ended.
It is remarkable that France has contributed so little to supply the Egyptian demand. Obviously it would be cheaper and more convenient to get gold from France than from England.

div.head: Plaque Investigation.
div.p: The Advisory Committee appointed by the Lister Institute of Preventive Medicine, and financed by the Indian Government, have recently published the reports of their Working Commission, which has been conducting operations in the Plague Research Laboratory, Parel, Bombay. Up to the present, the Commission has mainly concerned itself with the epizootic spread of plague among rats, and the means by which the disease may be communicated from that animal to man. The reports which have now been issued must be regarded as of a more or less preliminary nature, as it will be impossible for the Commission to give their final conclusions until the completion of their observations, which in many cases must be extended over a period of twelve months. The reports bring to light, says the "Globe," several facts of great interest; it has been ascertained that outbreaks of plague in India are in the great majority of cases preceded by an outbreak of disease among rays, and as there is abundance of evidence to show that this is the chief cause of plague epidemics it will at once be obvious that a knowledge of its causes and history is of paramount importance to us. It must be remembered that in India the rat lives chiefly in dwelling houses, and that the opportunities of the plague bacillus being transferred from the rat to man are, therefor, of constant occurrence. There are several ways in which the infection may be communicated, either by the rats soiling human food, or by parasites which infest the rats, and will also feed on man, or through direct poisoning from rat bites. Of these three causes the Commission has come to the conclusion that by far the greatest danger arises from the bites of parasites, and a series of experiments of a most intricate nature have been made which tends to uphold their opinion.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL,
div.p: Council of Ministora
The Council of Ministers will meet on Saturday next at Ras-el-Tic, under the presidency of the Khedive.
Undesirables
On Saturday last the Cairo police apprehended about 50 vagabonds 'of different nationalities and conducted them to the Gouvernorat, where they will be dealt with.
Drowning Accident.
A native ghaffir who was guarding the American steamer Duke of York at Alexandria on Friday-night, while walking along the quay, slipped and fell into the sea and was drowned.
Suez Canal.

On November 2, 17 vessels transited the Canal, and paid transit and passenger toll Fr. 436,167.75. Of these vessels, 9 were British, 4 German, 1 French, 1 Italian, 1 Danish, and 1 Austrian. They carried collectively 80,156 tons of cargo, and 631 passengers. The total reversed since November 1 is Fr. 802,988.08.
King's Birthday Parado.

Army officers desiring tickets for the reserved carriage enclosure at Abdin Square, Cairo, on the occasion of the colebration of his Majesty's birthday on the 9th inst, are requested to apply to A.A.G., Headquarters. There will also be a reserved enclosure for officers and their friends at the saluting point, and officers requiring tickets for their friends should apply as above, giving the nounos of the between tbo Cairo Gokarnorat and the Hellenio

Consulate General in Cairo, in regard to Alexander Kudai, the outlaw, who recently found his way back to Cairo, where he was rearrested, the authorities have decided to banish the man again to Greece. Accordingly, Kudai will arrive at Alexandria to-day guarded by police, who will see him safely on the steamer sailing for Pisæus this afternoon.
St. Mark's Church.

The selection of sacred music rendered yesterday in St. Mark's Church, Alexandria, at Mätins and Bronscng reflected great credit both on the choir and organist. In the morning the Anthem "No Shadows Yonder" (from A. R. Gaul's Holy City)' was sung with much tasta, and feeling. The tenor solo was rendered with good effect by Mr. Purvis, who has a fine tenor voice. The Evensong rejection "Nightfall" from "Ruth," by the same composer, was excellently sung. The choir numbered nineteen voices.
Savoy, Port Said.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Port Said, we notice : Major General Bullock, C.B., Mrs. and Miss Bullock, Col. Aylmer, Col. Wilson and family, Col. and Mrs. Cox, Major Marks, Capt. Young and family, Bimb. Symes, Crook-hank Pasha, Hon. and Lady Littleton, Sir William Willcock, Mrs. Wilward, Mr. E.H. Sandy, Mr. H. du Boulay, Mr. Crewe, Mr. A.P. Mark, Mr. Sharwey, Rev. Mrs. Urguhart, Dr. and Mrs. Wakeling, Mr. Weldon and family, Mme and Mille Du Brucq, Mrp. Leu priere, Mrs. Hayter, Mrs. Wood, Miss Wigram, Dr. and Mrs. Pain, Mr. Homphreys, Consul General and Mrs. Hummel.
In Athens.

The Greek Government has recently voted a subscription for the erection of a School of Languages in Athens. The advantage of knowing the principal modern languages is acknowledged everywhere. Thanks to the existence of the Berlitz Schools in Cairo (Sharia Kamel) and in Alexandria (Rosette), Egypt has been able to keep pace with European countries in the march of progress. [ADVT]

div.head: SINAI FRONTIER TRIBES.
div.p: ARAB CHIEFS DECORATED

The Arab chiefs of the frontier clans between Rafah and Akaba, whose visit to the War Office, Cairo, was recently reported in the "Gazette." have been presented by the Sirdar with decorations, swords, and robes of honour in the name of the Khedive.

The Sirdar, in bestowing the decorations, addressed the recipients in an elequent Arabic speech, thanking them in the name of the Khedive for their loyalty, and urging them to continue to show the proofs of devotion to the Khedive and his Government which they had given in the past.
Departure of Sirdar.

Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha left yesterday for Khartonm accompanied by several prominent Sudan officials, among whom were Mr. Currie and Major Stack. A large number of British and Egyptian officers of the Egyptian Army were at the station to bid good-bye to their chief.

div.head: THE INNISKILLINGS MARCH.
div.p: Reception at Mansourah

By the hearty cheers given for Mustapha Pasna Maher, the active and sympathetic Moudir, in response to his speech welcoming the squadron to Mansonrah, and equally hearty cheers were also given for Mr. F.T. Murdoch, the British consular agent.

In the evening the officers were entertained at dinner by the Moudir, and later on the party adjourned to the Mansourah Club, which took this occasion to inaugrate its new premises with a ball at which "All Mansourah" was present.

Dancing commenced at 9:45, and at midnight an excellent supper was served in one of the large saloons of the club. The Moudir again welcomed the guests in a few well chosen words, and informed them that the whole of the population of Mansourah both European and native had "united together" to welcome them. Major Pateraon, on behalf of himself, brother officers, and men of the squadron, returned thanks. Dancing then recommenced, and it was 3 a.m. before the Khedivial Hymn and "God Save the King" brought a most pleasant evening to a close.

On Saturday afternoon a "tournament" was held at the Mansourah Tennis Club, at which the officers were present, tea being provided by the president of the club, Mr. Murdoch. In the evening Mr. Murdoch also entertained the officers to dinner, the Moudir and a few other British residents also being present.
On Sunday morning, after a march through the town, the detachment proceeded on its journey, carrying with it the "hearty good wishes" of the entire population of Mansourah.

In commenting on the Menoufieh maize incident reported in our issue of Saturday, "AlMokattam" says: -"A few months ago, when the Denishwai affair took place, the fellaheen of Menoufish did not fear the Inniskilling Dragoons, whom they now welcome with open arms. Why? The answer is simple. It was the anti-occupation papers which stirred up the ignorant fellaheen at that time, when some of them published statements that 80 thousand Turkish troops were at the gate of Egypt, that some other battalions were in Alexandria; that Germany was co-operating with Turkey to make English withdraw from Egypt; that Lord Cromer had been abused by his countrymen and was to be dismissed, and that there was a National Party in Egypt, whose leader had gone to England and convinced the great men of that country to agree to his national aspirations, etc. But when the hue and cry of those papers was suppressed by the circumstances which contradicted their fatal utterances the previous effects of their threats to the British Occupation were removed from the minds of the people, especially those who are now welcoming and entertaining the British troops at Menonfish.

div.head: CAIRO ASSAULT CASE.
div.p: CONCLUDING EVIDENCE.
The following is a continuation of the report of the case, Waldberg v. Bennett, in H.B.M.'s Consular Court, Cairo, which was partly telephoned by our Cairo Correspondent on Saturday: -
Maître Carton de Wiart continued:
You asked for advertisements and begged for scraps of news at my office; but I never had the slightest conversation with you.
Plaintiff: Did you make any communication to me at your house?

Me Carton de Wiart: You wished to enter my house, but came no further than my garden. You then spoke to me till I cut you short, and as I turned my back on you I told you to take care what you were about.

Plaintiff had no further questions to ask the witness. Mr. Bennett was then cross-examined. He said he had seen the envelopes and the papers with marked passages on Me. Carton de Wiart's desk. He thought this was a case of "chantage." He telephoned to the plaintiff to call. He did not know whether the plaintiff answered. In the afternoon he came to the office about 3:10 p.m. and found plaintiff waiting outside. Plaintiff said : "I have an appointment with Maitre Carton de Wiart." He replied, "No; I sent for you," and then went into the office, telling him to follow.

"He stayed outside, so I called him in again. Pushed him out of the office door and him two blows on the side of the face with my hand open, or at least not clenched. At the entrance to the house I, literally and metaphorically, kicked him out. He used foul language, which I need not repeat, called a cab, and drove off.
Plaintiff: There was no one in the room when you assaulted me ? - No; no one on the European side. (Witness then explained the arrangement of the rooms in the office).
Was anyone on the native side ? - I cannot see round corners.
Did you say you would pay people to thrash me ?
What I said was, to the best of my recollection, to the effect that you would be thrashed if I had to pay for it to avoid dirtying my own hands on you.

Did you give a garbled account of this to the newspapers (Plaintiff here denounced the "Morning News").- I did not go to them. I met the Editor of the "Egyptian Morning News" at the Opera and gave him an answer to his questions a brief outline of the facts.

Mr. Le Breton then summed up for the defence. He pointed out that Mr. Bennett had committed no actual assault till bitten by plaintiff. That if any doubt remained as to the character of the Editor of "The Oriental Truth" he would beg the Court to suspend judgement till further witnesses were called. In any case plaintiff's conduct justified severe reprisals.

Captain Waldberg then addressed the Court in what appeared to be an Anglo-German dialect eked out by violent gesticulation. He declared that he repudiated all accusations of blackmail. "He exbected shustice," and concluded with the following striking paroration : "I don't want no damages because a Ladin Amurrican never demands money combensation (Hilarity). Wod I wan' is my glasses and the dwendy pounds if they have found them."

Captain Waldberg's command of the English language is so slight that we feel anxious to learn who was the author of some of the passages that have appeared from time to time in "The Oriental Truth," which show a better knowledge of English than the Captain appears to possess.

div.head: KHEDIVE'S NARROW ESCAPE.
div.p: Yesterday morning the Khedivial train, in which his Highness was traveling to Mariout, had a narrow escape from wreckage. Shortly before the passage of the Khedive's train a goods train running along the line dropped a buffer, which lay on the line near Nusah bridge. But happily the Khedivial train through striking the buffer, only received a slight jerk and it was not even necessary to stop it.

div.head: BANDMANN OPERA COMPANY.
div.p: "A CHINESE HONEYMOON."

"A Chinese Honeymoon" proved to be a better pieve than some of us expected, though without anything bery striking. As far as the company was concerned, it was quite well given. Good parts also were taken by Miss Leslie and Mr. Percival, neither of whom have been given much to do so far. Miss Leslie was the Princess Soo Soo, and rang very well, as did Mr. Percival as the Emperor. Both were a little "stiff" as far as acting went. We missed several old friends: Mr. Smith, Miss O'connor, and Miss Morra were all three absent. Miss Probyn was the hotel maid of all work, and really distinguished herself. "I want to be a lady" was admirably given by her. The best songs were "Chin Chin Ching a ling" (or whatever it was) by Miss Leslie, "The highly respectable very delectable Emperor" by Mr. Percival, the "Alagirl" by Miss Corlass (who, to our joy, was once more in great form), and "The Happy Land" by Mr. Cole. This last song was the gem of the evening. Mr. Cole and Miss. Corlass had a most excellent duet, "The Chinese Honeymoon." Indeed, all through they played admirably together as the Pineapple couple. Miss Corlass had also a most effective dance, masked. It was a very hideous mask, we must say, but we all knew her at once by her steps. Mr. Haydn as the Lord Chancellor, and Mr. Lester as the Lord High Admiral (looked like Mr. W.D. Night Watchman) were both Major's conducter was fairly good as the late; but hardly up to the won't even meet respond to his appeals.

Mr. Attwell was not singing well. The part and the play seemed uncongenial to him. It has its good points, but is really rather an absurd production with its silly little hits at society, - the song about tact, for example, Miss Corlass wasted much time and trouble in emphasizing points and words not worth her notice. Otherwise her acting and dancing were delightful. Mr. Harry Cole was at his greatest, and the stage as well as the audience were kept laughing all the time. His "Indian Club" dance, improvised with his torn coat, brought down the house, and Miss Corlass too. His phrenology lecture and his palmistry were beyond praise. Miss Morra and Mr. Lester were both quite good in their various parts: the cranium song and the "Fellow who might" were prettily given. Miss Morra had also a very attractive duet with Mr. Haydn - "Love Galloping," or some such title. Mr. Haydn's song about the "Dandy Man" was excellent. Miss Nina Leslie again had a fairly prominent part, and did it full justice; the dress suited her quite well.

One of the prettiest things of all was the octet in the second act. The ladies' dresses were delightful, and at least on of them - if not one and aff indeed - was much admired. But unfortunately the music grew so bad towards the end that we could but long for the curtain.

div.head: STONEWARE MANUFACTURE IN EGYPT
div.p: POSSIBLE NEW LOCAL INDUSTRY.

A report which opens up the possibility of regular stoneware manufacture in Egypt, instead of importing these articles, is that of Mr. Wilton Rix, the well known expert, formerly manager of Doulton's, who says in regards to two fo the clays from Khargeh Oasis sent him for assay and fire test :-

"I have pleasure to forward you..a fired sample of the two clays treated at the different temperatures as suitable for salt glazed vitrified drain pipes and Staffordshire blue bricks. The results in both cases are so admirable in every respect that they deserve the very careful attention of your directors. The clay No. 889 B, as you will see, takes the salt glaze very well and produces ware quite equal to that of the best English make. The clay No. 889 A will produce the metallic blue bricks such as come from the best Staffordshire brick works without any difficulty.….I may add that the clay No. 889 B, salt glazed as shown, is suitable for making all kinds of salt-glazed pottery ware such as is now made at Lambeth, Bristol, and Glasgow."

div.head: A NEW BANK.
div.p: Among the new companies to be floated in Egypt this season is a bank "de report" with a capital of 200,000 in 1 share. The success of the Comptoir Financier et Commercial d'Egypte hes been so great, and it has clearly met a great need on the part of the public, that it is not surprising that it should find competitors eager to enter on the same field of operations. The new bank will be floated as an Egyptian Company under British suspices. All the capital has already been subscribed.

div.head: CHRYSANTEMUM SHOW.
div.p: A.H.S. EXHIBITION AT SAN STEFANO.

The ninth Chryanthemum Show of the Alexandria Horticultural Society, which was held on Saturday and yesterday at San Stefano, was a great success. The groups seem to become larger every year, and the individual flowers more attractive. So great was the number of exhibits that every nook and corner of the Casino was full of plants and the only way of staging the collections arranged by the native gardeners was to put them with the vegetables. It seems clear that next year it will be absolutely necessary to erect a tent outside.

The most remarkable feature of all was not the groups arranged by the European gardeners, from whom we can expect taste, but the progress which the native gardeners made in staging large groups. Some few years ago such a thing was almost impossible; and it was only ten years ago that the society began to especially encourage the growth of chrysanthemums. When it started the flowers were small, and there was no encouragement to import new varieties. Now the flowers are equal to those of Europe, and one only had to look at the more important groups attentively to see that they contained many of Calvat's latest varieties. Perhaps the most beautiful of all which has just been imported is the little twisted like characteristic with the form rather like a yellow Madame Carnot, or a J.C. Warren. That in our opinion was the most beautiful flower of the Show. It was staged by Mr. Zervudachi.

Another novelty, for Egypt at least, the Tokyo, a werid looking flower, white in colour, with a strange second flower coming out of the centre, was shown by Toussoun Pasha. The small white chrysanthomum which was so to be really year in Mr. Zervudachi's group but was not efficient every exhibit this year high chrysanthemums. It stress its actors the whole length of the ball room.

The competition for the smaller groups of a hundred plants was very keen. Baron Felix de Meusaca, who is beginning to take great interest in chrysanthemums, obtained the first and Yehia Pasha the second prize. The competition for pots with fifteen blooms should be encouraged; they are effective and well grown, and present a pleasing effect for decorative purposes. But what one who is interested in chrysanthemums wish to know was, who would gain the 10 objet d'art, which was offered by Baron Felix de Menasce for twenty-four good blooms. The competitors had a long table apart, and the blooms were so large that they filled all the vacant space. There is no doubt that they were much admired by the public, and that Mr. Zervudachi well merited the first prize. Amongst his collection he had also the best chrysanthemum in the Show. There were so many competitors in the other classes that the committee decided to give extra prizes. The whole room was filled with enormous blooms, which seem to get larger every year, and consequantly it becomes more difficult for competitors to be certain winning prizes.

The Municipality had a room apart. Their group, however, was hors concours; but the committee decided to request the Municipality to be allowed to give Mr. Monfront the silver medal for the way the flowers were arranged and the manner in which they had been cultivated. Mr. E.C. Zervudachi showed us fine collection of Oattelaya labiata Autumnalia which were placed on a table in the centre of the ballroom.
The exhibitors of vegetables and fruit were not numerous; the only one of importance was Mrs. Grafton, who staged some fine bananas, anona, and other fruits.
The attendance on Saturday was good and included the leading members of the British and other European colonies; yesterday there must have been nearly two thousand people present.

The Horticultural Society and its committee are to be cordially congratulated on the progress that is being made year by year in the art of horticulture, thanks to their painstaking efforts. The judges were Mrs. Borchgrevink, Mrs. Crafton, and Messrs. Ebell, Monfront, Mallison, and Thierrard. The list of successful competitors follows:-
PRIZE LIST.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Ibrahim Hilmy and family have arrived at the Hotel Excelaior, Rome
Lord Cromer paid a visit to H.E. Mustapha Pasha Fehmy on Saturday at the Ministry of the Interior.

Lady Watts has returned to London from her travels in the East. She came as far as Malta in the Khedive's yacht, and from Alexandria she proceeded to Greece and visited most of the islands in the Achipelago on the S.S. Ismailia, one of the Khedivial mail steamers. Besides parts of Africa and Asia Minor, she visited many places of interest in Eastern Europe.
The passengers by the Italian steamer. Tebe, which arrived from Europe yesterday, included Cairo from Garoness Acton, Comm. and Mme. and Mrs. Cookson, Dr. Breccia
Constantine Cotta Bey, secretary to the Council of Ministers, has returned from leave and resumed his official duties.
We are sorry to learn that Mr. John Home, manager of the National Bank, is suffering from dengue fever.
Mr. W.E. Kingsford, who has been seriously ill all the summer, and has undergone two operations for apendicitis, is returning to Ghezireh with Mrs. Kingford and family on the 18th inst.
Lieutenant H.M. Appleton 6th (Iuniskilling) Dragoons, has been placed on duty with the draft for his regiment embarking for Egypt on December 1st on board the Brasmar Castle.
Mrs. Sidney H. Wells has left Cairo or Assiout. He is expected to return on Thursday.
Dr. and Mrs. A.T.M. Bentley and the Misses Bentley have arrived from Englad and are staying at the Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan.
Mrs. R. Barber and Mr. and Mrs. C. Barber have returned to Halte No. 2, Ramleh from Europe.
Mr. and Miss Manley have returned from Europe by the S.S. Hohenzollern.
Dr. Faris Nimr, Ph. D., has returned to Cairo.

Among those who arrived this morning by the Khedivial Mail S.S. Osmanieh, from Turkey and Greece we notice Tambaco Pasha, Mustapha Bey Menzelawi, Mr. and Mrs. J. Williamson, Mr. and Mrs. H. Williamson, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon, Mr. G. Gordon, Mr. E. Wilkinson, Mrs. Gunn, Miss Whitall, Mr. and Miss Sevastopoulo, Mrs. Calouyani, Mr. and Miss Bereketti, and Mr. Zambacopoulo.

The death is announced at Liverpool of Mr. Norman Wylie, in the sixty-eighth year of his age. The deceased who retired from business about twelve years ago, spent many years of his early life in the inferior of Egypt, where he was engaged in the construction of irrigation works on the Nile, and he took sheer interest in the country.

div.head: Bulletin De La Bourse
div.p: (Auiourd' hui à midi et demie.)

Anjourd'hui, dornier jour de la liquidation, une ronction partielle s'est produite à l'occasion des ventes forcees qui ont eu lien ; la baisse du coton américain dans lequel des égyptions se trouvent intéressés a également influencé les vendeurs.

La National Bank hausse de 27 1/16 à 27 8/8, la Cassa di Sconto de 242 et 237 à 243 1/4 et 238 1/2, la Banque d'Athènes de 147 1/4 a 147 1/2, tandis que le Coraptoir réactionne de 7 8/16 at de 6 15/16 a 7 1/8 et 6 7/8 l'action et de 53 a 52 1/2 la part de tondateur, l'Agricolé do 9 25/32 a 9 3/4, l'Obligation no velle Crédit Foncier de 273 a 271, le Crédit Franco Egyptien de 5 5/8 a 5 9/16, la Banque d'Oreint de 134 à 133 ½.

De 17 7/16 la Daïra fléchit à 17 5/16, la Delta Land de 4 7/32 a 4 3/3?, la Building Lands de 4 31/32 à 4 15/16 et l'Union Foncière de 6 9/16 à 6 1/2, pendant que l'Urbaine's avance de 6 5/8 à 6 11/16.

La Delta Light gagne 1/16 a 12 1/16 et la Salt and Soda 6 pence à 25/3 ; les Cotton Mills reculent de 7/9 & 7/3; l'Anglo-American Nile progresse de 5 13/16 a 5 15/16, tandis que les Nungovich Hotels perdent 1/8 a 18 5/16; les Sucreries montent de 26 a 28 1/2, et l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 38/9 à 39/9.
L'animation a porté spécialement sur la National Bank, la Salt and Sods, la Cassa di Sconto, la Delta Land, les Estates et le Comptoir.

Parmi les Societes qui vont etre lancees en Egypts an cours de cette saison, se trouve une banque de report au capital de *200,000 en actions de *1 chaque. Le succes obtenu par le Comptoir Financier et Commercial d'Egypte a ete tel et a repondu a de si grands besoins qu'il nest pas etonnant de voir d'antres Societes embrasser le meme champ d operations. Le nouvelle banque sera lancee comme Compagnie egyptienne sous les suspices de capitalistes anglale. Le capital est deja integralement souscrit
Le Credit Lyonnais a rec matin par le bateau du Lloyd Austrichien "Habsburg" 60 caisses de *5,000 et 6 caisses contenant ensemble *20,000, soit en tont *320,000.

La Corporation des agents de change du Claire a ouvert an concoure entre architectes de tostes nationalites pour la presentation d'un projet de palais destine a la Bourse du Caire. Le premiere condition du cashier des charges porte que tous les projets doivent etre presentes an Caire, a la Corporation des agents de change da Caire, avant le 31 October. U vais exemple que celui que donneraient les agents de change en se muttant volontairement du cote de l'arbitraire

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: Notes Et Critiques
Le Caire, November 3.

Le tanx de l'escompte libre a Londres a eleve hier de 1/8 a 6% Au Stock Exchange le consolide anglais n'en a pas moins hausse de 1/8 a 86 1/2. L'Unifiee a e e cotee 102 1/2, ex-coupon. La National Bank a gagne 1/8 a 27 1/2, la Daira 1/4 a 17 3/8 et la Delta Light 1/8 a 12 1/8. L Agricole est demeuree inchangee a 9 7/8.
A Paris, l'action Credit Foncier Egyptien eat renseignee en hausse de 3 trancs a 785. La Banque d' Athenes a progresse a 147. L'Emprunt russe 1906 a passe de 85 10 a 85 60.

loi, le marché ne s'est pas trop laissé influencer par la hausse du taux de l'escompte libre à Londres ; il a compris que o'est là un effet transitoire de la cherte des reports à la liquidation de fin de mois. Aussi bien la tendance sa pas été mauvaise et une certaine tarmeté a pré lomine, malgré tout, sur une bonne partie de la cote.

A la vérité, les affaires out été, dans l'ensemble, plutot restreintes, ce qui est le résultat naturel du fait que la liquidation ne sera complètement terminée que dans les premiers jours de la semaine prochaine.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National, en bonne tendance, « avangé 27 7/16-1/2. L'Agricole a faibli 9 3/4. La Cousa 'di Sconte a progressé à 239-240. La Barque d'Athènes est revenue à 145. Le Comptoir Financier s'est inscrit à 7 1/8-3/16 l'action ancienne et 6 7/8 la nouvelle ; la part de fondateur a atteint 53. La Bar que d'Abyssinie s'est alourdie à 5 9/16-3/8,
Le Crédit Foncier a rétrogradé à 783-784 et la Daira Sanieh a 17 3/8-7/16. La Bébéra a cloturé a 44-44 1/2. L'Union Foncière a été offerte & 6 5/8. .
L'Immobilière a résotiuncé à 384.Bien tenus, les Improvements ont gagné 1/8 a 6 9/16.
Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux ont été négociées à 4 5/8 et la part de fondatear a 96. L'action Allotment s'est raffermie 4 1/83/16; la part de fondateur est revenue à 172.

L'action Express Nile a été l'objet d'une bonne dem sude à 4 3/16. L'Anglo-American Nile s'est consolidé à 5 15/16. Les Frigorifiques ont perdu 1/16 à 4 11/16. L'action Brasserie des Pyramides a mo'li à 138 et la part de dividende à 78. Les Automobiles ont reculé à 6 1/8 3/16

Dans le groupe des valeurs ho'elières, les Nungovich ont été échanges a 18 5/16-3/8. Les Egyptian ont réactionné à 7 5,8. Les Upper Egypt ont été soutenus & 5 9/16. Les National ont fléchi a 4 1/16 1/8 et leur part de fondo tear a 76.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Lania été ramenés à 4 1/8 3/16 et les Hooker a 1 1/8. Les Estates ont été, à un moment donné, largement ramassés à 2 1/4 pour fioir à 2 3/16-1/4; leur part de fondateur s'est alourdie à 15 15 1/8 Les Salt and Soda ont bénéficié de plus d'un shelling à 25 sh. 3. La Kbedivial Mail a progressé à 38 sh. 9 et les Construccions à 1 5/8-11/16. Les New Egyptian ont clôturé a 33 sh. 3. Les Cotton Mills, fortement demandés, ont atteint 8 sh. pour terminer offerts à ce prix.
Les rumeurs répandues récemment au sujet d'un projet de fusion entre la Compagnie lmmol i ière d'Egypte et la Compagnie Agricole du Nil n'ont éé encore ni oonfirmées, ni démenties.

Bien qu'on ne sache guère sur quelles bases cette fusion pourrait êrre faite, on prétend néanmoins qne le projet rencontrerait une vive opposition de la part d'un puissant groupe d'actionnaires de la Compagnie Immobilière et même d'une partie du Conseil d'administration de cette société.

On ne tardera pas, apparemment, à être édifié à cet égard. Eu attendant, on annonce d'Anvers (-iège social de la Compagnie Agricole du Nil) qu'il est question d'une prochaine émis ion de 5 milions de francs d'obligations pour accrolitre les ressources de la Société.
Soivant des informations d'Alexandrie, il se confirme que l'émission de la Sidi Salem Estates of Egypt Co. aurait lieu dans la seconde quinzaine du mois courant.

On sait que cette Société, constitnée à Londres le 25 Juin dernier, au capital de £440.385,5 sh., représenté par 110.000 actions de £1 et 7.725 parts de fondateur à 1 sh., a acheté à la Société anonyme du Béhéra le domaine de Sidi Salem d'une sope fisie de 14.000 feddans, à raison d'environ £40 le feddan.

Aiusi qu'on l'a deja annouce il sera, pare il, alloue aux actionnaires de la Behera un droit de preference lors de la repartition de la Sidi Salem Estates Co., comma cela ete fait lors de l'emission de l'Union Foneirere

Pressage et Depots sont prevenus que l'assemblee generale ordinaire du 29 Octobre dernier a fixe les intereis et le dividende pour l'exercice 1905-1906 a 10% soit a par action. Un acompte de *0.12 ayant ete reparti en Mars dernier, le solde, soit *1.8 sh par action, sera paye a partir du 5 novembre courant par la Barque Imperiale Ottomane contre remise du coupon No. 16.

div.head:
New York Governorship
Epithetic Electoral Campaign
Roosevelt Stigmatizes Hearst.

div.p: The electional campaign for the Governor ship of New York surpasses all previous elections in America for passion and vehemence. Epithets of "liar," "sneak," blackguard," "rowdy" etc., etc., are constantly exchanged.

President Roosevelt, who is unable to personally participate, has commissioned Mr. Root to declare publicly that Mr. Hearst's election would bring injury and discredit to honest labour and honest capital.

Mr. Root denounced Mr. Hearst as a deliberate demagogue, an exploiter of sensationalism, an apologist for the murder of President Mac Kinley, an upstirrer of useless discontent. After Mr. Root's speech the betting in Wall Street in favour of Mr. Hughes advanced to 4 to 1
(Reuter)

div.head:
NORTH POLE EXPEDITION
COMMANDER PEARY'S RETURN.

div.p: According to advices received at Hopedale (Labrador) the explorer Commander Peary is returning after having reached 87.6' degrees, which is the farthest point yet attained.
(Reuter)

Commander Peary's homeward voyage was an incessant battle against ice and storms. There were no deaths or illness, although sometimes the men were starving and compelled to eat their dogs. The expedition left New York on the 16th July, 1905.
(Reuter)

The Council of Ministers has approved the Ministerial Declaration, which will be read on Monday. This Declaration is more advanced than those of all previons Cabinets. It announces numerous projects in the interior ; abroad, it intends to maintain the Franco-Russian Alliance and the previous friendships formed by France, which will continue to follow a policy of rectitude, resting on defensive foroes. (Havas)

A declaration which M. Clemenceau will read in the Chamber of Deputies on Monday asserts that the Cabinet intends to maintain tbe Franco Russian Alliance and all the precions friendships formed by Prance. France will continue to pursue with the Powers the straightforward policy which bas enabled her to take one of the first places in the world, and which she will support with her defensive forces. The Separation Law is to be applied without persecution, but firmly. Nomerous extensive reforms dealing with income tax and old-age pensions are foreshadowed. (Reuter)

According to a semi-official statement, published simultaneously here and in Vienna, Baron Lexa d'Aehrenthal and Signor Tittoni exchanged friendly declarations resulting in an agreement. They are acting in full accord in order to render ever more cordial and intimate the excellent relations between the two Governments. (Reuter)
A Japanese has been arrested who is supposed to be an engineer officer. He was discovered making maps of the railways, rivers, and bridges. (Reuter)

A number of sailors who were imprisoned in connection with the Sveaborg mutiny put their jailers in irons and liberated 200 of their comrades. Troops were called by telephone and suppressed the motiny. (Havas)
Certain members of the lecionary Union of the Russian People" have been arrested here. (Reuter)

The damage done by the storm to the seven ports in the vicinity of Toulon was most extensive. The latest advices show that many families bave been rendered destitute. The military and naval authorities are endeavouring to obtain Government aid for them. (Reuter)

div.head:
ENGLAND'S MUNICIPAL ELECTIONS
A WARNING TO GOVERNMENT.
MODERATES' UNPARALLELED GAINS.

div.p: All the newspapers comment on the surprising results of the municipal elections, indicated by the fact that only two London boroughs returned Progressive candidates. The Liberal Press, while attributing the defeat to lavish expenditure in the past, says that the Moderates made use of Conservative political machinery in the attempt to re-capture London. They admit that the public dread of Socialism is induced by the truculent tone of the Labourite speakers.
The Conservative Press considers the result of the election indicative of growing dissatisfaction with the Government, and warns Unionists that the call to arms may come when least expected.
Mr. Balfour, speaking in the City, said that the results sbowed that the country was beginning to see through the platitudinous pretences, by means of which tbe Government obtained office.

Mr. Arquitb, speaking at Manchester, said that the Government intended, without delay, to endow the Orange River Colony to the fullest extent with self-government. He criticised very strongly the reconstitution of the Education Bill by the House of Lords, and said that the Government would not yield if it could, and could not if it would. (Router)

Galway election.--- Mr. Stephen Gwynn, Nationalist candidate, has been elected with 983 votes, in place of Mr. Devlin, retired Mr. Shawe Taylor, the Devolutionist candidate, secured 517 votes. Fighting with shillelaghs continued all day. The police were powerless to restore order.
Later.
Six persons have been removed to hospital. Forty arrests have been made. (Reuter)

div.head:
SPANISH SOVEREIGNS AT MALAGA.
VISIT TO BRITISH FLEET.

div.p: The King and Queen have arrived here. They were enthuiastically received. Prince Louis of Battenberg welcomed them at the station. The town was dressed with British and Spaniss flags. (Reuter)

The King and Queen of Spain have gone to Malaga on a visit to the British Fleet anchored there. It has been currently stated in Court circles that the King, in speaking of the approaching visit, exclaimed:

"Since Philip II. no Spanish King visited England until I myself went there; and I not only visited England, but I married an English princess, and I believe when I have done that I can also pay a visit to Gibraltar !"
The Wireless Telegraphy Convention has been signed.
It is understood that the British delegates are satisfied with the results, and believe that the naval interests have been fully safeguarded. (Reuter)
Rugby Football. The South Africans beat Gloucester by 23 points to nil. (Reuter)

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY
div.p: The following is the official communication of the agenda of the next meeting of Alexandria Municipality to be held on the 7th inst: --
1° Communications diverses.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: FOOTBALL
RAILWAY INSTITUTE. R.A.M.C.

This match was played at Gheziret Badrane on Friday, 2nd instant, before a very good attendance. Neither side were at full strength, but the game was exceedingly fast and brimful of interest from start to finish. The Railway men won the toes and elected to defend the Shoubra goal. The 'Medicoes' had slightly the best of the opening exchanges, but Hayes and Windsor were very safe at back.

The Institute forwards soon found their feet, and some very exciting play took place. Hayes played a brilliant game at left back for the home team, and time after time pulled up the visitors' forwards. Just before the interval Captain Bostock got right througb the backs and a score seemed certain. But Stephenson was equal to the occasion, and brought off a fine save. Half time soon arrived with the score sheet blank.

The second half was even faster than the first, and but for some determined play by both pairs of backs both goals would have been penetrated more than once. The two goalkeepers brought off several good saves, Stephenson on two occasions saving when a goal seemed inevitable. As time went on both sides exerted themselves to the utmost to score, but the deciding goal did not come till the last minute of the game. Newton then scored by slipping the ball past Bevan, who had just managed to keep out a shot from Wheal. The game ended a few seconds later in victory for the Institute by the only goal scored in the match.

div.head: PIGEON SHOOTING.
div.p: MALTESE VICTORIA SCHOOL.

The pigeon-shooting meeting held on Saturday afternoon for the benefit of the above excellent educational institution, at the RondPoint Shooting Club, kindly let for the occasion by the proprietors, Messrs. Tedeschi, Pereirs, and Milani, was a great success. The weather was excellent, the attendance ex-
ceptionally good, and sport most interesting, over twenty well known sportsmen having competed.

During the intervals the Maltese Philharmonic Society ("La Vallette") played a select programme under the able bâton of Cav. Ugo Pucciarelli, assisted by Mr. Pipio, which 7 was much appreciated and applauded.

The Cup offered by the Manufacture Française d'Armes et Cycles de St. Etienne was won by Mr. Zarani, who obtained the largest number of pigeons during the afternoon. Mr. Zarani also won the silver cognac service, offered by Mr. Alfred Pace, to the competitor who obtained the largest number of prizes, he having succeeded in getting the 2nd, 5th, and 7th prizes. The 1st prize was won by Mr. Galogheropoulo, the 3rd by M. Stini, the 4th by Mr. Pereirs, the 6th by Mr. Elias, the 8th by Mr. Mina, the 9th and 11th by Mr. Fumel, and the 10th and 12th by Mr. Ablitt.

The success of this pleasant and sporting afternoon is mainly due to the sportsmen, wbo kindly took part in the meeting, and to the members of the school committee, Mr. Léandre Camilleri, their chairman, being most energetic and successful, and reodering the gathering, which included a great number of ladies, a most pleasant and agreeable afternoon.

div.head: CAIRO BRITISH RIFLE CLUB.
div.p: The new season commenced on November 1, and already the club has received a large addition of new members, and the ranges are well patronised. Shooting days will, as before, be Fridays and Saturdays, and to meet the convenience of some of the members who prefer shooting early in the day, the targets are available on Friday morning as well as the afternoon.

The programme for the season will include, besides a number of matches, competitions for a challenge cup kindly offered to the club by Mr. A.H. Hooker, a tyro competition for a rifle given by the Hon. F. O. Lindley, fortnightly sboots for spoons, and the usual shoots for the medals for marksmen which Dr. H. Milton has kindly offered again.

The club is thus looking forward to a busy and interesting season, British subjects desi rous of becoming members are invited to communicate with the Hon. Secretary, Turf Club, who will be pleased to give particulars, or to come out to Tourah any Friday afternoon.
The first spoon was won by Mr. Fletcher with 77+6=83. A match will take place at Tourah next Friday afternoon against the 2nd Batt. Iuniskilling Fusiliers.

div.head: Los Pilules de Dehaut De Paris
div.p: s'hesitent pas a se purger, quand elles on ont pesoin. Elles no craignent ni le degout ni la fatique, parce que, a l'oppose des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opere bien que lorequ'il est pris avec de bons et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, cafe, the. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'boure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mioux, salon ses occupations. Le fatigue de la purgation etant annules par reffet de la bonne alimentation, es no decide aisement a recommencer autant de fois que cela est necessaire.
